questions.question: What is the accepted minimum period of sexual cohabitation required to establish thediagnosis of infertility in a couple?
What is the most common cause of male infertility?
questions.explanation: The most common cause of male infertility is disorders of spermatogenesis.Male factor is the cause of infertility in about 20% of infertile couples. However, it is acontributing factor for infertility in 50% of cases.

questions.question: The secretion of FSH in men is inhibited by the negative feedback effect of
questions.explanation: The secretion of FSH in men is inhibited by the negative feedback effect of inhibin secreted bySertoli cells.GnRH stimulates the anterior pituitary gland to secrete FSH (follicle-stimulating hormone) andLH (luteinizing hormone). FSH acts on Sertoli cells while LH triggers testosterone secretion by theLeydig cells. Sertoli cells secrete inhibin B which in turn inhibits FSH but stimulate LH secretion.770Male HPG AxisHypothalamusGnRHAnteriorpituitaryLHFSHTestesTestosterone

questions.question: A 25-year-old man underwent semen analysis as a part of an infertility workup. The resultsare given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: •In the given clinical scenario, the most likely diagnosis is normospermia.Different types of disorders of sperms are as follows:Aspermia is defined as the absence of semen.• Oligospermia is defined as a sperm concentration <15 million/mL.• Severe oligospermia is defined as a sperm concentration of <5 million/mL.•Teratospermia is defined as the presence of abnormal sperm morphology.• Asthenospermia is defined as the absence of motile sperms or diminished sperm motility.• Necrospermia is defined as the presence of dead sperms.Note: Morphology > motility is the most important marker in sperm analysis.

questions.question: While going through a patient's file at an infertility clinic, you note his semen analysis isreported to be normal. What had his semen leukocyte level likely been?
questions.explanation: The normal leucocyte level in human semen is approximately 1 million/ml.The semen sample should be collected after 2-7 days of ejaculatory abstinence. The patient shouldcollect the sample by masturbation at the doctor's office. If not possible, then the sample may becollected at home and delivered to the laboratory within an hour of collection.

questions.question: What does azoospermia refer to?
questions.explanation: 771Azoospermia is defined as the complete absence of sperm in semen. Other types of spermdisorders are as follows:• Aspermia is defined as the absence of semen.• Oligospermia is defined as a sperm concentration <15 million/mL.• Severe oligospermia is defined as a sperm concentration of <5 million/mL.•Teratospermia is defined as the presence of abnormal sperm morphology.• Asthenospermia is defined as the absence of motile sperms or diminished sperm motility.• Necrospermia is defined as the presence of dead sperms.

questions.question: A young couple being treated for infertility require donor semen for artificial insemination.Which of the following is the likely cause of infertility here?

options.D: Presence of antisperm antibodies in the cervical mucucs

questions.explanation: Artificial insemination with donor semen is done in cases of infertility where the husband hasazoospermia.Azoospermia is defined as a complete absence of sperms. Hence artificial insemination with thehusband's/partner's semen cannot be performed.Indications for artificial insemination with husband's/partner's semen are:•Chronic medical disorder• Oligospermia after sperm washout.Impotence• Premature and retrograde ejaculation• Hypospadias• Antisperm antibodies in cervical mucus• Unexplained infertility- direct intraperitoneal insemination (DIPI) is done• HIV-positive male or femaleX-Y fractionation of sperms for sex selection in cases of genetic and chromosomal abnormalitiesIndications for artificial insemination with donor semen are:.Azoospermia• Uncorrectable immunological factors.Genetic disease in husband/partner• Chronic ill healthSperms can be frozen and used later for artificial insemination e.g. if the husband requires toundergo radiotherapy or chemotherapy, or if the husband is a frequent traveler and is notavailable at the time of ovulation.Artificial insemination techniques include:• Intrauterine Insemination (IUI)772• Intrafallopian-tube Insemination• Intracervical Insemination●• Direct Intraperitoneal Insemination (DIPI)Steps required to do artificial insemination are:• The semen is washed to remove abnormal sperms, debris, and seminal plasma containingantibodies. It is concentrated, and its quality is improved by the 'swim up technique' or by the useof the Percoll gradient.••Semen with normal sperms and good motility is obtained.Around the time of ovulation, semen obtained is inseminated into the female genital tract. About0.5 ml of semen is injected 36 hours after hCG injection when the ovarian follicle reaches 20 mm.

questions.question: Indications for artificial insemination with donor's semen are all except
questions.explanation: Artificial insemination with donor's semen is not indicated in idiopathic male infertility. Thepreferred treatment in such cases is in vitro fertilization (IVF).

questions.question: A 50-year-old man with erectile dysfunction requires treatment with sildenafil. Which of thefollowing is not a contraindication for the use of this drug?
questions.explanation: Pulmonary hypertension is an indication for the use of sildenafil.The contraindications for the use of sildenafil are:.Retinitis pigmentosa• Diabetic retinopathy• Patient on antihypertensive drugs, nitrates• Cardiac disease, previous myocardial infarct, strokeIn the treatment of erectile dysfunction, sildenafil in the dose of 25-100 mg is given 1 hour beforeintercourse. However, it does not improve libido.

questions.question: What is the most common cause of infertility in women?
questions.explanation: The most common cause for infertility in women is due to ovarian causes.According to WHO, female factor infertility was reported in 37% of infertile couples in developedcountries. Male factor infertility was reported in 8% of infertile couples while 35% of couples hadboth male and female factor infertility.The major ovarian causes of infertility are:• Anovulation (PCOS)• Decreased ovarian reserve, e.g., premature menopause773In women with ovulatory disorders, clomifene and metformin increase ovulation and pregnancyrates.Less common factors responsible for female infertility are:• Endometriosis• Pelvic adhesions•Tubal blockage• Other tubal abnormalities• Hyperprolactinemia

questions.question: A 34-year-old woman presented with secondary infertility following radiation therapy forHodgkin's lymphoma. You plan to test her ovarian reserve. Which of the following is the bestindicator of this parameter?
questions.explanation: Among the given options, the level of follicular stimulating hormone (FSH) is the best indicator ofovarian reserve.Ovarian reserve is the capacity of the ovary to produce eggs. FSH levels are measured in the earlyfollicular phase on day 2 or 3 of the menstrual cycle.A high FSH level indicates that the ovarian reserve is getting depleted and fewer oocytes arepresent in the ovary. FSH is high in ovarian hypofunction and postmenopausal women.Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) is a better marker than FSH for ovarian reserve. Unlike FSH, itslevels can be estimated at any time of the cycle. AMH is produced by the granulosa cells in ovarianfollicles.Note: Studies show that AMH levels decrease under the current use of oral contraceptive pills andtobacco smoking.

questions.question: What will be the level of the anti-Mullerian hormone in low ovarian reserve?763
questions.explanation: In low ovarian reserve, the level of anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) will be <1 ng/ml.AMH is a glycoprotein secreted by the granulosa cells of the primordial follicle of the ovary. Ithelps in oocyte maturation and mono-follicular development. AMH is also used in assessingovarian reserve.In women, AMH is always absent during embryogenesis and is secreted by the granulosa cellsafter puberty. It helps in follicular development and oocyte maturation. Estimation of serum AMHis used in the study of ovarian reserve in female infertility and secondary amenorrhoea.In men, AMH starts to be secreted by the Sertoli cells in the testes by the 7th week of intrauterinelife. It continues until puberty. It inhibits the development of the Müllerian system. The absenceof AMH results in the development of hermaphroditism.774AMH levels in ng/Interpretationml2-6.8<1>10NormalPoor ovarian reservePCOD Hyperstimulation syndrome

questions.question: In a woman diagnosed with infertility, which of the following antihormonal substance can beused to induce ovulation?
questions.explanation: Clomiphene citrate is an antihormonal substance used to induce ovulation in a patient diagnosedwith infertility. Ovulation can be induced by giving clomiphene citrate 50 mg daily, starting fromday 2 to day 6 of the menstrual cycle for 5 days.

questions.question: A woman with irregular periods was evaluated for infertility, and underwent an endometrialbiopsy. The histology image is given below. Which phase is seen here?
questions.explanation: The image depicts the proliferative phase of the endometrium.During menstruation, the endometrium goes through three phases, namely; proliferative,secretory, and menstrual phases. Their histological features are given below:Proliferative phase• The glands of the functional layer are simple tubules with regular epithelium.• Arteries become more coiled and spiralled.• The endometrium is thick, the stoma is compact and short straight glands are present.The image below shows proliferative endometriumSecretory phase775•The secretory phase of the endometrium begins on the 15th day and persists until the onset ofmenstruation.• Subnuclear vacuolation (presumptive evidence of progesterone activity)• Corkscrew-shaped glandsThe image below shows secretory endometriumMenstrual phase: Glands shrink with prominent vessels and haemorrhagic spots.

questions.question: The microscopic appearance of the cervical mucus of a woman having irregular periods andinfertility is shown in the image below. In which phase of the menstrual cycle was this samplelikely taken?
questions.explanation: The image shows the characteristic ferning pattern of cervical mucus which is seen in theestrogenic phase of the menstrual cycle.A specimen of cervical mucus is obtained using a platinum loop or pipette. This is spread on aclean glass slide and allowed to dry. When viewed under the low-power microscope, a palm leaf orfern type pattern is seen in the follicular phase. The ferning is due to the presence of sodiumchloride in the mucus secreted under the effect of estrogen.This pattern disappears after ovulation. If it was previously present, its disappearance ispresumptive evidence of corpus luteum activity. Under the influence of progesterone, the cervicalmucus becomes thick and tenacious and impenetrable to sperms and bacteria.The below image shows the microscopic appearance of dried cervical mucus showing the fernappearance.776

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false about the Miller-Kurzrok test?

options.A: Penetration of > 3 cm at 30 minutes is considered normal
options.B: Cervical mucus is placed alongside husband's semen on a glass slide
options.C: It is done at the time of ovulation
options.D: Jerky motility of sperm is considered normal

questions.explanation: In the Miller-Kurzrok test, sperm acquiring jerky motility after penetrating cervical mucus isconsidered abnormal.The Miller-Kurzrok test is a special test done in semen analysis to diagnose the cause of infertility.It is an in vitro test of sperm-mucus interaction.It is based on the basic principle that a normal cervical mucus permits invasion by motile sperms.It is done at the time of ovulation. The test consists of placing cervical mucus on a glass slidealongside the specimen of the husband's semen and studying the penetration of sperms under themicroscope. The penetration of sperm > 3 cm into the mucus at 30 minutes is considerednormal.Other special tests in semen analysis include:•Sperm penetration test• Semen-cervical mucus contact test•Postcoital test (Sims' or Huhner's test)

questions.question: 765A post-coital test was done in a couple who presented with an inability to conceive despitestaying together for 4 years and having unprotected intercourse. Which of the followingconditions cannot be detected by this test?
questions.explanation: The post-coital test can not detect a fallopian tube block. It can evaluate the following conditions:Sperm count••Sperm morphology• Ferning during the estrogenic effect• Ovulation777•The ability of the cervical mucous to allow sperm penetration• Detection of anti-sperm antibodies in the cervical mucousIn the post-coital test, the couple is advised to have intercourse early in the morning close to theovulation phase. The woman is asked to visit the clinic within 2 hours of having intercourse. Themucus is aspirated from the cervical canal and spread over a glass slide. Another smear madefrom the posterior fornix serves as a control.On microscopy, 10-50 motile sperms are normally seen per high-power field. The cervical mucusis also examined for its quantity and viscosity. The post-coital test is useless in the presence ofcervical infection.An immunological factor causing infertility is encountered in around 5% of infertile couples.

questions.question: During your posting in the infertility clinic, you notice the following instrument. Identify it.
questions.explanation: The instrument in the given image is Rubin's cannula.It is used while performing a hysterosalpingogram (HSG). The cone prevents the retrogradespillage of the dye into the vagina, while the dye is instilled into the uterine cavity. Thisinvestigation is performed to study tubal patency in women.Another cannula that can be used to perform HSG is Spackman cannula. It allows for theintra-operative manipulation of both anteverted and retroverted uterus.

questions.question: A patient with secondary amenorrhea and infertility is diagnosed to have Ashermansyndrome. Hysteroscopic evaluation revealed 30% adhesions of the endometrial surfaces, butno agglutination of the uterine wall. How would you classify this patient?

options.D: Cannot be classified with the given information

questions.explanation: This patient would be classified as a case of moderate Asherman syndrome as 30% adhesions ofthe endometrial surfaces are present.Asherman syndrome (uterine synechiae) is classified as follows:• Minimal: <25% adhesion involves the uterine cavity, flimsy adhesions involving the fundusand tubal ostia..• Moderate: 25–70% adhesion of the endometrial surfaces, but no agglutination of the uterinewall.• Severe: 75% adhesions with agglutination and thick adhesions.Asherman syndrome can present in the following ways:• Secondary amenorrhea• Oligomenorrhoea•• Dysmenorrhoea• Habitual abortions• InfertilityThe causes of Asherman syndrome are:778• Dilatation and curettage (D&C)• Medical termination of pregnancy (MTP), spontaneous abortions, recurrent abortions• Uterine packing in postpartum haemorrhage• Uterine infection•Tubercular endometritis

questions.question: A 30-year-old patient with complaints of inability to conceive underwent the followinginvestigation. Which of the following is false about the same?

options.A: The best time to perform it is before ovulation
options.B: It is perfomed to detect uterine anomalies
options.C: It is the first-line investigation in genital tuberculosis
options.D: Premedication can be done with atropine

questions.explanation: The given image shows a hysterosalpingogram (HSG). HSG is contraindicated in genitaltuberculosis.Procedure of HSG:⚫It is best performed in the period between the last day of menses to ovulation, usually on the9th/10th day of the cycle.• 10-15ml radioopaque dye is injected into the uterine cavity via Leech-Wilkinson cannula, Rubin'scannula, or Foley's catheter.• Fluoroscopy is performed as the dye passes through the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes.• If the tubes are patent, the dye will spill out of the tubal ostia into the peritoneum, and smear theadjacent bowel.It is used for the detection of:⚫ Tubal block - It can be due to:•• Strictures - fibrotic block.Inspissated amorphous material• Tubal spasm - This can occur in apprehensive patients. It is prevented by premedication withatropine and analgesia..• Uterine anomalies• Uterine polyps• Uterine synechiae• The feasibility of tuboplasty, by studying the location and extent of tubal pathology.Contraindications:●• Genital tract infections, such as genital tuberculosis. This is due to the risk of spreadinginfection.•Bleeding• Suspected pregnancy•Allergy to the dye• Premenstrual phase:• If by chance pregnancy has occurred, it may be dislodged.779•Thick endometrium might prevent the smooth flow of the dye, at the cornual end.• There is a risk of embolism and endometriosis if HSG is done during this phase.

questions.question: A patient who has been trying to conceive for the past 6 months underwenthysterosalpingography (HSG). The findings are given below. What is your interpretation?767R
questions.explanation: The given image shows a normal hysterosalpingogram (HSG). Both fallopian tubes are patent witha spill into the peritoneal cavity.The following images show the findings of an abnormal hysterosalpingogram:The hysterosalpingogram given below shows bilateral dilated fallopian tubes with no free spillsuggestive of bilateral hydrosalpinx:The hysterosalpingogram given below shows a unicornuate uterus:780The hysterosalpingogram given below shows a bicornuate uterus/septate uterus:There is an overlap in the appearance of the bicornuate uterus and septate/sub-septate uterus onHSG. The distinction lies in the shape of the uterine fundus, which is usually not visible on HSG.An ultrasound or MRI should be done to differentiate between these conditions if intervention isplanned.RThe hysterosalpingogram given below shows filling defects:

questions.question: Which the following are not the advantages of fertiloscopy over laparoscopy?

options.B: Trauma is avoided as no trocar is needed
options.D: Good view of the anterior surface of the ovary and genital organs

questions.explanation: Fertiloscopy helps in obtaining a good view of the posterior surface (and not the anterior surface)of the ovary and genital organs. This is an advantage of fertiloscopy over laparoscopy.The other advantages of fertiloscopy over laparoscopy are:781• The Trendelenburg position is not needed. The procedure can be done in a lithotomy position• Trauma can be avoided as no trocar is needed• No CO2: Hydroperitoneum with saline• Peritoneal spill can be seenFertiloscopy is a new mini-invasive diagnostic technique that allows the visualization of theposterior pelvis. In this technique, an optical device is introduced into the pouch of Douglas,through the posterior vaginal fornix, under general/local anaesthesia.It can also be used for small interventions, such as adhesiolysis, ovarian drilling, coagulation ofendometriosis spots and to perform chromosalpingoscopy and salpingoscopy. With fertiloscopy,surgical intervention can be avoided and it is a good alternative to diagnostic laparoscopy.The image given below is of a fertiloscope.FTO 1.40ystperativeFertiloscopy

questions.question: A 26-year-old woman underwent a workup for primary infertility. On hysterosalpingography,there was a bilateral cornual block. What is the next step in management?
questions.explanation: In the given clinical scenario, the next step in management will be hysteroscopy andlaparoscopy-guided surgery.Tubal contractions, particularly cornual spasms, can give an incorrect impression of proximalfallopian tube obstruction (a false-positive result) on hysterosalpingography. Laparoscopy withchromotubation is therefore considered to confirm the diagnosis of cornual spasm. Laparoscopy isboth diagnostic and therapeutic in this condition.Hysteroscopy is an operative procedure that provides an endoscopic view of the endometrialcavity and tubal ostia via the cervix, performed in the preovulatory phase. It canbe diagnostic or therapeutic. It is the gold standard investigation for visualizing the uterine cavityand tubal ostia.•Contraindications to hysteroscopy are as follows:• Acute genital tract infection (Eg: genital herpes infection)782• Viable intrauterine pregnancy•⚫ During menstruation, the view is obscured, and the infection rate is high.• Scarred uterus and enlarged uterus of size ≥ 12 weeks are relative contraindications.• Cervical stenosis can cause cervical tears and uterine perforation.•Cardiopulmonary disorder due to increased risk of fluid overload and pulmonary edema.Known cases of cervical cancerLaparoscopy is the gold standard for the evaluation of tubal factors in infertility, commonly donein the proliferative phase. It can be diagnostic or therapeutic.•Benefits of laparoscopic evaluation:Tubes: For detection of tubal patency, block (site and side), motility, hydrosalpinx change,peritubal adhesions, fimbrial agglutination• Ovaries: PCOS changes, endometriosis, PID, adhesions•• Uterus: Anomalies, fibroids• Peritoneal factors: Adhesions, PID, endometriosis, tuberculosis• Therapy at the same sitting (as appropriate)Therapeuticindications of hys Diagnosticindications of hystteroscopyUterine septumAsherman syndrome Retained IUCDPolypectomySubmucous fibroidAbnormal uterine bleeding Tuba1 sterilization using sclerosing agentseroscopyTo study the endocervical mucosal liningCongenital malformations of the uterusEndometrial tuberculosisMisplaced IUCDEndometrial lesionsEndometrial polypAsherman syndromeCornual tubal blockageDiagnosticAge >35 years History of pelvic pain, dyspareunia, pelvic surgery, adhesionsAbnormal HSGFailure to conceive after areasonable period (6 months)with normal HSGWomen with comorbid pelvic pathology(PID, endometriosis)Therapeutic (Operative)Unexplained infertilityReconstructive tubal surgeryAdhesiolysis Fulguration of endometriotic implantsOvarian drilling in PCOSGIFT and ZIFT procedures

questions.question: A woman came to the clinic complaining of amenorrhoea and inability to conceive. She hadundergone hypophysectomy for a tumour a year ago. What would be the best line ofmanagement for her?

options.D: Human menopausal gonadotrophin, followed by hCG

questions.explanation: The best line of management for the given patient is human menopausal gonadotropin (hMG)followed by hCG.783The patients who have undergone hypophysectomy i.e. removal of the pituitary gland, can notproduce endogenous gonadotropins. Exogenous gonadotropins such as hMG are given to suchpatients. Timed administration of hCG is needed to induce ovulation after the follicle hasmatured.The human menopausal gonadotropin is an extract of urine from postmenopausal women. Itcontains FSH and LH in the required ratio for follicular growth.Clomiphene, letrozole, and GnRH analogs stimulate the release of gonadotropins from thepituitary gland. These are not helpful in a patient whose pituitary gland has been removed.784
